title: Cost of living crisis: How are families coping? - BBC News

segments.text: The cost of living crisis continues to squeeze household budgets across Britain
Food prices have risen by more than twenty percent in two years
Energy bills remain far above pre pandemic levels
despite some reduction from their peak
Families on the lowest incomes are being hit hardest
Food banks report record demand for their services
The Trussell Trust distributed more emergency food parcels than ever before
Housing costs are another major pressure point
Rents have surged as mortgage rates pushed landlords to increase charges
Many young people say home ownership is now completely out of reach
The Bank of England has raised interest rates to combat inflation
but this has increased mortgage payments for millions of homeowners
Creating a painful squeeze from both directions
Workers across multiple sectors have gone on strike
demanding pay rises that keep pace with inflation
Nurses teachers and railway workers have all taken industrial action
The government says wage increases must be affordable
to avoid fuelling further inflation in the economy
Childcare costs remain among the highest in the developed world
Many parents say they cannot afford to return to work
because nursery fees consume most of their salary
The government has announced expanded free childcare provision
but providers warn they cannot deliver it without more funding
Pensioners are also feeling the strain
Many are choosing between heating their homes and eating properly
The triple lock on state pensions has provided some protection
but fixed income savings have been eroded by persistent inflation
Mental health charities report a surge in anxiety related calls
as financial stress takes a heavy toll on wellbeing
Economists say the worst may be over
with inflation gradually falling back towards target
But for many families the damage has already been done
Savings have been depleted and debts have accumulated
Recovery from this crisis will take years not months
The cost of living remains the number one concern for voters
and will be a defining issue at the next general election
Immigration is often linked to housing pressures in public debate
though economists dispute the strength of this connection
What is clear is that millions of people are struggling
in ways that would have seemed unimaginable just a few years ago
The social contract between government and citizens is being tested
as basic necessities become unaffordable for working families
Britain faces a fundamental question about what kind of society it wants to be
and whether prosperity can be more fairly shared
The answers will shape the country for decades to come
